newsitem.title: FINLAND: NO INFLATION RISK SEEN IN FINNISH INCOME TAX CUTS.
newsitem.headline: NO INFLATION RISK SEEN IN FINNISH INCOME TAX CUTS.

text.p: An increase in purchasing power and consumption from a bigger-than-expected Finnish 1997 income tax cut will not boost inflation and the central bank should have no need to hike rates for at least a year, economists say.
The government's state budget proposal agreed last week includes income tax reductions worth 5.5 billion markka, and economists have been quick to upgrade consumption forecasts.
"But in the short term one would need a lot of imagination to come up with something that would constitute an inflation threat," said economist Risto Murto at brokerage Selin Finance.

"During the course of 1997, I see no possibility whatsoever for a need to arise to tighten monetary policy," said Mikael Ingberg, head of research at the Pellervo Institute for Economic Research (PTT).

Three of four economists polled by Reuters on Wednesday said it would take at least a year, and maybe 18 or even 24 months, before the Bank of Finland could conceivably see its core inflation target threatened.
But Petteri Hirvonen, economist at brokerage Davy Protos said the Bank might judge that inflation could start accelerating sometime during the second half of 1997.

"There is so far no risk in that direction, but in early 1997 it is already possible that (the Bank) ... thinks it should take action to pre-empt a rise (in inflation) otherwise setting in half a year later," he said.
But the majority view was that neither headline inflation nor the underlying inflation rate monitored by the central bank would pick up noticeably for quite some time.
In its most recent detailed statement on inflation prospects, the Bank of Finland on June 17 said: "The conditions for a moderate inflation development over the next few years are favourable.

"This in turn creates good conditions for interest rates to remain steady," it said. On July 5, the central bank lowered the tender rate to 3.50 percent from 3.60 percent and said the outlook was unchanged from June.
For the foreseeable future the tender rate -- the Bank's chief monetary policy tool -- was likely to remain at the current 3.50 percent or fall slightly, the economists said.
"The monetary policy outlook is for a prolonged period of calm," Ingberg said.
"A rise in interest rates may be in sight one or two years from now," Murto said.
Jukka Kero, economist at the Central Chamber of Commerce, said the Bank should make it clear to a broader audience than the financial markets that there was no upward pressure on interst rates.
"I would regard (a hike) as a precipitate measure, absurdly overestimating the (inflation) risk if it happened within one year," he said.

"They should make it clear, at least implicitly as the German Bundesbank seems to have been doing, that the tender rate will remain unchanged for a long time or that any possible move would be downwards," Kero said.
Partly due to the income tax cuts promised by the government, many private consumption forecasts for 1997 have been lifted to three percent from around 2.5 percent earlier.

Finland's biggest trade union group, the 1.1-million mainly blue-collar member Central Organisation of Finnish Trade Unions (SAK), said in a statement on Tuesday that purchasing power of a typical SAK member family would rise three percent next year.

Economists said strengthening private consumption would continue to focus on durables and semi-durables like cars, white goods and other household appliances. Home electronics sales, home refurbishing and tourism and foreign travel would increase.
This meant imports would rise, but not in a way that would threaten Finland's current account surplus, they said.

"We are on very solid ground," said Ingberg at PTT. The annual C/A surplus widely forecast at around 20 billion markka at least until 1998 corresponded to nearly four percent of gross domestic product, he noted.
"It is difficult to see such growth in imports that it woulds pose a real problem for the external balance and economic policy," he said.
